private_information: I can only manipulate blocks whose labels are vowels (E, A, I).
I can only interact with blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move only one block at a time.
vowel_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks so that A is on top of B, B is on top of C, C is on top of D, D is on top of E, E is on top of F, F is on top of G, G is on top of H, H is on top of I, I is on top of J, J is on top of K, K is on top of L, L is on top of M, M is on top of N, and N is on the table.

private_information: I can only manipulate blocks whose labels are consonants (F, B, N, L, G, C, J, M, D, H, K).
I can only interact with blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move only one block at a time.
consonant_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks so that A is on top of B, B is on top of C, C is on top of D, D is on top of E, E is on top of F, F is on top of G, G is on top of H, H is on top of I, I is on top of J, J is on top of K, K is on top of L, L is on top of M, M is on top of N, and N is on the table.

private_information: I coordinate the two agents and must integrate their partial models into a single planning problem.
I produce the final PDDL domain and problem compatible with the FastDownwards planner.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a complete PDDL domain and problem (FastDownwards-compatible) that achieves the global block stacking goal using the capabilities and constraints of the two agents.

public_information: Blocks present: E, A, F, B, N, L, I, G, C, J, M, D, H, K.
Initial stacks on the table (bottom to top):
- Stack1: E (on table), F on E, J on F, D on J.
- Stack2: A (on table), B on A, N on B.
- Stack3: L (on table), I on L, G on I, C on G, M on C, H on M, K on H.
Only the top block of any stack can be picked up by an agent.
An agent may move only one block at a time.
One agent can only manipulate vowel-labeled blocks (E, A, I).
The other agent can only manipulate consonant-labeled blocks (F, B, N, L, G, C, J, M, D, H, K).
The goal configuration is a single tower where, from top to bottom: A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, L on M, M on N, and N on the table.

model.system_prompt: You are an agent that inspects and reports a partial symbolic model of the world restricted to the blocks you can manipulate (vowel-labeled blocks). You do not produce PDDL. Instead, you provide a clear, structured set of facts describing the initial relations you observe for the vowel blocks (for example, predicates like (on E F), (ontable E), (clear X), or a small JSON/predicate listing). Do not invent information about consonant blocks beyond their relation to vowel blocks when observable (e.g., if a vowel block is on or under a consonant, report that relation).

You are an agent that inspects and reports a partial symbolic model of the world restricted to the blocks you can manipulate (consonant-labeled blocks). You do not produce PDDL. Instead, you provide a clear, structured set of facts describing the initial relations you observe for the consonant blocks (for example, predicates like (on B A), (ontable L), (clear X), or a small JSON/predicate listing). Do not invent information about vowel blocks beyond their relation to consonant blocks when observable.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent planning and PDDL authoring. Your job is to take the partial structured models produced by the agents and integrate them into a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem file suitable for the FastDownwards planner (STRIPS-compatible). Produce both a domain and a problem. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Ensure action schemas reflect that each agent can only move top blocks, only one block at a time, and enforce the vowel/consonant manipulation constraints by keeping agent-specific actions distinct (e.g., move-vowel, move-consonant). The produced PDDL should be consistent, fully grounded where appropriate for the problem file, and directly usable with FastDownwards.
pddl.prompt:
There are two agents in an environment that are planning to solve a block-stacking task. You will receive their partial structured models. You need to integrate them and produce a FastDownwards-compatible PDDL domain and problem that achieve the global goal:
{agents->orchestrator->goal}
Here is the public information about the world:
{environment->public_information}
Here is the partial model reported by the vowel agent:
{model_vowel}
Here is the partial model reported by the consonant agent:
{model_consonant}
Guidelines:
 - Keep the actions of the two agents distinct (e.g., move-vowel, move-consonant) and ensure preconditions enforce that an agent can only pick a top block and only of its allowed class (vowel or consonant).
 - Include predicates sufficient to express on(X Y), ontable(X), clear(X), and which agent can move which block.
 - The domain should be STRIPS-compatible for FastDownwards; avoid non-supported features unless you specify them clearly.
 - Produce a fully specified domain and a problem that names all objects and the initial state derived from the integrated models.
Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags, and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
